text: Good morning everyone. If you would collect your thoughts and pause your conversations,
this is a very low mic, we're going to get started this morning. So this morning we are
talking about STEAM. Now if you were here last night or tuned in for the live stream,
this is a generative dialogue conference that we're having. There's no prescripted presentations,
there's nothing like that. The goal of this conference is to really evolve a conversation
over the course of three days. We're on day two now, we have a very full day, so we'll
have lots of conversations to evolve. But this morning we're going to talk about STEAM
and the future of education. So for those of you who don't know what STEAM is, it stands
for science, technology, engineering, art, math. The idea is that it's kind of as well
rounded holistic approach to education where students aren't just siloed into one discipline
or another, but they understand how disciplines are related to each other, can help each other,
work with each other. And it's a new educational movement. It was started in 2008 after there
was a lot of buzz about STEM, which came from our government wanting people to go into STEM
so we could have the competitive edge in our 21st century space races. But STEAM is adding
the art in there, it's adding the design and the humanities. And I think all of us in this
room pretty much agree that's important to some degree. So this morning we have five
experts in various facets of STEAM education and remodeling education in this 21st century.
I will be filling in for my colleague, Narav Patel, who I work with at Rutgers. I'll be
talking about what Rutgers is doing in this vein. And I will hand it over to Zach to do
the rest of the introductions. So if each participant could raise their hand, as I call their name
so that our viewers online will know who you are. First we have Roger Molina. Roger Molina
is an art science researcher, space scientist, and astronomer and editor of Leonardo. Tara
Rota. Tara is the manager of the BioArt Lab at the School of Visual Arts and a practicing
artist. As Julia mentioned, filling in for Narav Patel is Julia Bontane, founder of
SciArt Center. Elizabeth Waters. Elizabeth is a democracy and knowledge consultant and
educator at Enquiring Minds USA. Alana Quinn. Alana is an exhibit and program organizer at
the cultural program at the National Academy of Sciences. And Tyler A. Aloe. Tyler is
co-founder of Eureka's, an artist, and an award-winning team specialist. With that, let's
begin the conversation. Okay. So I wanted to start off by asking my colleague, Roger. We
have talked a number of times about STEAM education. How do we build a model for it? Is
there one curriculum? Are there multiple curriculums? I'll get to my question to you in a second.
But to kind of explain my role here, in addition to my work with SciArt, I am an adjunct innovator
in residence at Rutgers University. They made up that title for me. I still don't know what
it means, although I've had it for a little while now. But basically my role is to drum
up cross disciplinary activity on campus. I teach a January STEAM course. But when I
started teaching this class, I went to make the syllabus. And then as soon as I sat down,
I realized, gee, how do I do this? Not make the syllabus part. I know how to do that. But
how do I make a syllabus for something that doesn't have a roadmap to it? It's not an
English class where you read X amount of books and you write X amount of essays. It's really
kind of uncharted territory. So I started to reach out to other people, including a lot
of people in this room, and Roger saying, okay, like, what's your STEAM syllabus look
like? What are the goals of a STEAM class? How do you teach someone in a cross-disciplinary
manner for an 11-day class like mine or for a four-month class like a regular semester?
So that's when I got started with this conversation about a year and a half ago. And I realized
that every person involved in STEAM kind of has their own approach. They're all very
like-minded. But part of the reason I wanted to talk about this this morning was that so
we could kind of come together and continue nailing down like we were last night with
collaboration. What are the goals and maybe how do we define it better so that we can
all do better in our own work? So I know that you've had a lot of thoughts about this, Roger,
especially when it comes to educating cross-disciplinary people, especially at the graduate level. So
if you want to speak to that a little bit, I'd love to hear more.
Okay, so let me just begin with a little bit of context. So I was born of an English mother
and a Texan father in Paris. So I come from a very hybrid cultural background, which I
know affects my thinking. Second thing is I worked for 30, 40 years as an astrophysicist
building telescopes to put on satellites. I've experienced the thrill of discovery. And
so I've had the joyful experience of discovering things that people didn't know before. In
parallel with that, as was mentioned, I'm the executive editor of a number of publications
at MIT Press called the Leonardo Publications, which seeks to document and advocate the work
of all our discussion. And we're now celebrating our 50th anniversary. Five years ago, I was
forced to retire in France, because in France there's a mandatory retirement age in the
universities of 65. And I got this incredible offer in Dallas to open a not science lab,
funded by Rich Texan with all the implications that comes with, although they don't meddle
in what I'm doing. And I have true academic freedom, which is slightly frightening today
when we look at the state of education in general. My teaching contract says I will
teach one course a semester to graduate students on a topic of my choice. And that's in writing.
And so I've never taught the same thing twice. My seminars are typically a dozen students.
And what's fascinating and exciting is that the students come from very different disciplinary
backgrounds. So in the seminar this year, I have someone who's working on our center
for brain health, working on games for autistic children. I'm working with a young man who's
in GIS, geographic information systems. And he's been scanning buildings on the campus
before they're pulled down and making holograms of them. I have students that are students,
that are using new ways of expressing themselves. So let me tell you, it's really difficult
to figure out what it is we want to teach or what we think people should learn. And I
think one of the problems I have is I think universities have reached the limit of their
usefulness because they try to teach for the normal student. And let me tell you, none
of the students in my seminar are normal. They all have hybrid interests, multiple interests.
I was a narrow astronomer for 30 years. And let me tell you, I did astronomy 24 hours
a day a night. They all are trying to figure out how the university is going to help them
do a career that mixes their hybrid interests. And universities just don't think that way.
So I think the future of STEM education is outside of the university.
Well, it's interesting, you're saying that student demand is causing a change in education
or at least maybe that's part of it. I definitely experience the same with my students and
I'm sure that you guys do too. They're just not satisfied with, I don't know, maybe the
way we went to school where you just kind of focus in on one thing.
Tara, so you run a really amazing lab that I was a student at SVA, so I had the pleasure
of meeting Tara as the lab manager at SVA. Can you talk a bit about what's going on there?
I think maybe what sets it apart, ordinarily when we think about STEM, we think about
integrating, bringing the arts into science and technology and engineering and math. But
in our lab, it's a bioart lab at the School of Visual Arts. It was founded in 2011 by
Suzanne Anchor. We essentially do the reverse. We put the STEM toolbox in the hands of art
students. Our curriculum is project-based learning, so we tend to work backwards. We
put it in their hands and then follow their curiosity and untangle the logistics to lay
some more formal and technical groundwork. They get a crash course and all things biology.
A lot of it is material oriented, so we work with a lot of organisms that have image and
mold-making capabilities. They paint with bacteria and grow sculptures out of mushrooms
and bacterial cellulose. They do a lot of food transformations and work quite a bit with
DNA and a bit of plant modification. It's a spectrum. For the most part, they're all
undergraduate art students that have little to no background in the sciences. They're
really coming in as a blank slate. We definitely see that shift throughout the semester. They
approach the lab initially and it's a sterile facility and what feels like an academic field
that they don't belong to. Within a few weeks, they've figured out how to navigate the space
and they start approaching it as they would any of their other studio facilities. They
come in and they can manipulate and shape life and get a more personal grasp on some of the
advancements in biotechnology and explore their concerns about the biological world.
For the most part, it is a project-based material oriented studio facility, but it's a spectrum.
On the other end, as a group, we often collaborate on longer-term, more academic projects as well.
For the most part, we function as a studio space.
I wonder, what's your experience with these kind of typical art school students who come
in and all of a sudden they're immersed in science?
I think that's sort of how we shaped our curriculum. Immediately, when you put something
in front of an artist, they want to start manipulating it. They don't want to know all
of the details. They want to dive in. We've accommodated that. We've figured out how to
restructure ordinary workshops or educational seminars in a way in which they get hooked
and invested. Then we can sort of follow their concerns and unravel that. I would say they
are boundless. They have no hesitation, endless questions, and no desire to follow any of
the rules. As lab manager, it makes it a little tricky for me. I tend to be the naysayer.
As an artist running in a bio lab, we definitely follow the rules forwards and backwards. I
think one of the things that's really hard for an art student or someone that's not familiar
with a laboratory space is to recognize the difference in context. A lot of times when
we're talking about cultures or contamination, we'll say a moldy loaf of bread in your dorm
room is a few mist sandwiches. But in the bio lab, it's a hazard and it has to be terminated
immediately. I think for them, some of these very contextual differences about even things
that they encounter in their domestic day-to-day lives are quite interesting for them.
What about you, Tyler, working with younger students in this field?
We also are doing project-based learning, but a lot of what we're doing is trying to teach
different types of literacy. I would say over the last year, year and a half, really, the
focus has been more on an engineering literacy. People are trying to reintroduce and redefine
vocational training, mostly around computer technology, 3D modeling printers and things
like that. Schools are investing a lot into these labs, but they don't have the projects
to actually do anything with them or the knowledge. Some of that knowledge takes years to acquire.
So really what we're trying to do from a very early age, and we do work all the way through
with college students and even adult learners, is to develop projects that are teaching different
skill sets, whether it's engineering, but also the vocabulary that goes with it. To be able
to problem-solve, use your creativity and children especially are like artists. They're
not bound by anything. They have lots of questions, don't really care about the answers necessarily
to begin with, what they're interested in is exploring and then figuring out why something
doesn't work and then going back and maybe fixing it so it does work. And so a lot of
times what we're talking about too when we're going in and training teachers is developing
tools for the teachers to be able to change the context, the subject matter. The subject
matter becomes kind of the inspiration for the students. All learners learn in different
ways visually, some tactile. And so by developing these projects that are truly kind of trans
disciplinary, you're able to also bring out the strengths in different learners. If that makes
sense because so often in schools, you know with our data-driven kind of models that we have,
it's really based more on the tests. Reading, writing, math, science is not really highly valued
either. So what kids are getting is you know you don't get really chemistry until you're in middle
or high school and you only get kind of a certain type of chemistry where I remember going to school
as a kid and you were constantly getting bits of information to the point where maybe by high
school you were figuring out what your passions were and what you were good at so by the time you
got to college you could focus a little bit more directly on something.
Okay so my burning question of the day and I know that early of the hour and I know you guys
have your own too. Is it possible to develop a standard steam curriculum? Is that something we
should do? I would say no. I think as we work and we work from the west coast to the east coast,
all age learners is that really people are so driven by the tests and you go into schools.
Teachers don't have the freedom anymore to develop lesson plans that are able to transfer
knowledge to students. Every year there's a new set of standards that they're trying to deal with
and there's these assessments and really kids from an early age are being taught that there's a
right and a wrong way to do things and I think that bringing the arts back into STEM
you know and really expanding on that definition of what ARK is gives learners of all ages that
opportunity to say there is no right or wrong. This is really more about play. It's more about
expressing my interest and learning more about my interest, doing the research and it doesn't have
to be right or wrong and then you can carry that over and I think this is where some of that
transdisciplinary conversation was going last night is that through that freedom then you can kind
of focus in on the science of it or other aspects of it but to give people the space to be creative
without the right or the wrong and so by putting standards to it I think we would kind of mess
up what's going on with the movement as a whole. I definitely agree but I also just totally disagree
because I think like a lot of us here we want to see STEAM like educators want to see STEAM take
off and be implemented. How do you implement something without blueprint? How do you teach
someone who's not a STEAM educator to be one?
Well let me just mention we're just finishing a project right now. I was just discussing with
Harvey and how in the beltway they want evidence that STEAM is a good thing
and they only accept certain kinds of evidence and test scores. He's obviously part of that
landscape. So one of the things that Peter West and Aldecina articulated was well
can you give me really good examples of what STEM involves STEAM involves? Just give me 20 really
good examples that you could explain to a congressperson. And so I've been working with a PhD student
now for a year with about 20 nominators and it's such a diverse landscape of what people are doing.
So it's not like there is a STEAM example that's the example. There are about 20,
well we have 20 right now, but each one of you probably would come up with 20 different maybe
overlapping examples of why we're so excited about what's going on and why we think school
systems should pay attention. And the trouble is our systems are uncomfortable with that
ambiguity as Harvey was saying to me. As you say, it's not a right or wrong answer. It's a process
that might lead you to somewhere where you couldn't have gone otherwise and school systems hate that.
I mean it's really a very difficult problem.
I never heard about STEAM until I met Julia so I know very little about it. So if I'm going to say
anything or ask questions that I'm it's stupid I apologize beforehand. But what I'm not clear about
is one when does this STEAM education begin? Second is what is the goal of this education and three
has it been gone on long enough for you to be able to say this is what happens when somebody goes
through the STEAM programs. What is what is it they do when a 30 year old has gone through this
whole program. What is it doing and how is that being through that education has made him different
from somebody like me who never went through that education. So yes I was going to say I think the
thing that the question I have for other people is in your examples of what STEAM education looks
like. What is the relative balance of practices versus content. My background is as a neuroscientist
I'm interested in development and memory and hormones and moving into education and what I love
most about changes in science education are the discussions that happen around the next generation
science standards because it's multi-dimensional and one very important part of that is practices
and certainly in the work that I do in elementary education now we're talking about
how do you practice curiosity how do you practice creativity there's a lot of mythology that surrounds
those things it's actually things you do not as a person not the things you make.
So I think the what a STEAM student would look like as a 30 year old or a 40 year old
someone coming out of an educational system would be somebody who's confident in their ability to
explore their world and identify questions and generate solutions for themselves
and then discuss it with other people like I think those are the four core things for me.
We already have a lot of people who are like that.
Maybe the audience I see some furrowed brows in the audience I'm not sure.
I think internally but there is something reinforcing about getting someone to the table that feels
less than qualified I don't know much about stereotype threat but I get the impression that
it is a way to get people involved I know with our art students
they have no hesitation to make art and if they were to sit down and be asked to do a research
or science experiment there would be great aversion but when we set it on the table as art before
they know it they've done science and they feel a lot more capable not only as an individual but
as a maker and I think them being able to demystify some of the technical aspects about their biological
world gives them a more intimate understanding and even a sense of authority which is really
empowering.
Yeah and also importantly the people who go through STEAM education they're not going to grow up
to be prejudiced about art or science or technology or engineering or math or literature you know
these are people who are going to understand and equally value all of the disciplines that we have
and I think that's the real difference and that creates a situation where say someone is a STEAM
education but they grow up to be you know a mathematician it means that they might be more
open to collaborating like we were talking about last night to solve a problem or you know it might
mean that they just run in social circles that are outside of their own discipline I mean STEAM has
this really it's hard to define and the reason that we are kind of skirting around it is because
there's not one definition there's not one curriculum but but it's a whole whole-bodied mindset.
Let me just jump in to try and this discussion is not old not new I'm sorry.
It's at least a hundred thousand years old and so there were hunters and gatherers
and probably the hunters got trained to hunt and the gatherers got trained to gather
but then occasionally there were a few people that did both and they learned things in hunting
that really helped the gathering and so I think one of the problems is our school systems have
gotten so narrow that that fluidity between different ways of knowing and doing you know in the middle
ages you were either making you know you were a horse shoemaker or a horse shoemaker and you had to
decide which guild you were in there was the guild of shoemakers and the guild but what happened then
is these academies appeared that bridged the guilds right and so the the early academies was an effort
to to do that in the last century we had holistic studies into into creative studies into
disciplinary studies so roughly every generation there's a group of people that feels that the
system is keeping the hybrids or the osmosis between the disciplines from really happening
so I think STEAM is a new expression of that very long need to so that people both learn and teach
in ways which allow that lateral transfer. Over the last 15-20 years I've been actively involved in
creating interdisciplinary meetings here and so I'm and as a result of that I have learned
that tremendous amount and it has opened my eyes to a lot of things that before in my narrow discipline
I couldn't look at think about and use it to improve my own understanding including within my own
discipline so that has been an interdisciplinary conversation that have assisted and has helped
but I have a sense that what you mean by STEAM and STEAM education is something a lot more
structured and concrete than just you know hanging around with people from different
discipline and talking to them so that's what my question was about so if I can for where we go
with it. If I could talk a little bit about the relevancy and what a student would look like
getting out of school at 30. Monica and I oftentimes are asked to go into at-risk schools
and work with students so a couple years ago we developed a whole suite of projects around
simple machines which in common core standards kids get in second and third grade. About 40
percent English language learners they were probably rated about 60 percent proficiency
they were probably right around that with the tendons rating. We were working with the science
teacher and over the course of his semester working with second and third graders you know in those
communities oftentimes the kids don't have a lot of time with their parents and so there's there's
great gaps in where these students are coming into school too and by the end of the semester we had
gone you know from these very low ratings to 96 percent attendance rating about 87 percent
proficiency rating and a lot of this was based on the fact that one we're working with English
language learners but two through these projects that we developed we're doing things like story
boarding templates and atomic theater boxes so the kids are having to develop characters they're
having to develop story outlines and then they're actually having to do the engineering and put
together these boxes so that they can crank their toys and again so this is very transdisciplinary
but what you start seeing at an early age is that all kids excel at different levels and that
confidence that they get from seeing how somebody who might not excel at reading and writing is now
excelling at engineering and so you're also starting to get kids in an early age to start working
together but I would say also since we've been doing this long enough we've had students in our
programs for four or five years and oftentimes what we see is this intuitive understanding that
they start to get of these subject matters and I think this is where the conversation was going
last night a little bit too is that artists are very intuitive about the world when you think
about the golden section you know artists were using this long before scientists philosophers
actually put the math to it to decipher what it was Jackson Pollock paintings you know later now
that we have the technology you know explore fractal design and theory I'm sure he did not know what
he was doing and I don't even think they were talking about fractals back then right but so
this intuitive understanding of the world is something that we really have gotten away from
because we've become so specialized in our fields in the way that we teach subjects and
apply it in education that what we're not allowing kids to do from an early age is start to develop
that intuitive understanding of the world that they live in and to really start figuring out what
they excel at so that that becomes kind of their focus in life. Yes this is having at all educational
levels and there are definitely different approaches depending like what age or teaching. I'm going
to ask Alana to jump in here because she is graciously filling in for a colleague of hers from the
National Academy of Sciences and you can kind of describe the effort that's been going on at the
NAS in terms of identifying the steam landscape. Sure so there is a lot of anecdotal evidence about
the benefits of a steam or steam education to include the humanities. The first time I've heard
that one. Oh really? So the academy has decided to undertake a two-year study on evidence of the
value of integrating arts and humanities into STEM education specifically at the undergraduate
and graduate level and the study looks at different programs throughout the US and the findings will
actually be published this coming spring. So they're not ready to talk about it yet. Yeah but it looks
at a variety of programs like it I think ASU has a lot of very integrated programs. Olin College
of Engineering has a few programs a few courses that combine different disciplines so it's really
looking at a variety of these programs and will set forth a resource for best practices so if you
were a professor at a university and you were interested in getting involved in this field how
might you go about it this could be a good resource. And are they still accepting submissions? You know
for evidence? No I think that ended in May so they're kind of wrapping up the study at this point.
But yeah it's been going on for a little while really looking forward to see what they come up
with. Me too. I'd like to say I do think the humanities are an important part of it when we
talk about the A and STEAM so much of what we're doing is actually putting in that historical
and cultural context. You know it's very easy to take current technology and take it back 5,000
years to see how that thought process has evolved. It's also something kids get excited about because
as kids like to say anytime before cell phones was the dark ages.
I'm glad you just brought that up because I despite the fact that I'm a STEAM practitioner I
like really hate the acronym. I'm catchy you can say funny things like as STEAM just a bunch of hot
air. Which I don't know if we ever settled on that one. But yeah the acronym waves out
humanities like the arts are not the humanities and maybe it's a disservice to talk about that way.
So is there another word for STEAM? Like what's the next gen? I think redefining how we think of
art is really a better conversation because really when you think about what is art what ends up
and the annals of history it's really what's important as a cultural significance. You know that
knowledge at the time the technology whatever it is that's really what you're learning about
when you're learning about art history and culture. We recently had a group of children
toward the lab that were from PS I believe 92. On a handful of other STEAM programs will come
to check out the lab and more than once we've been showing them around maybe you know feeding
avianus fly traps and fingernail clippings or another task of sorts and I kept hearing the
children say to each other that's so steamy and they're using it as an additive and at first I was
like okay I'm officially old so that's homeschool but I have no idea what it means and then and this
was maybe two years ago before STEAM was an acronym that I was very familiar with and then it clicked
that's the way that they were referring to a spectrum of all things awesome and for them it
was hype it was cool and steamy sounds pretty good all things awesome yeah because there are many
artists who came out of their rhod
it all yeah let me just jump in so I think the way we're phrasing the question is part of the
problem and we get into the subject of taxonomies science humanities engineering math
that's not how the world is organized right this table doesn't care what discipline you've come
from and so and the problems we have trouble with fuzzy taxonomies universities hate them because
you kind of have a department of fuzzy things and so I think part of the challenge you know as you
said like there've been hundreds thousands of places that have done what we're talking about
over over the centuries and so how do we think differently about what we're trying to do when I
got to Dallas I got exposed to and I'm my close collaborator is Cassini Nazir who's a design professor
and I'm a scientist I'm an engineer I've designed things but let me tell you my idea of design was
so narrow so he says okay and this is part of some of the design vocabulary so what is the social
outcome you're trying to achieve through what you're doing become rich and famous make a better
world find someone to marry have a family and depending on the social outcome you need to approach
it differently so what is the social outcome you're trying to achieve then the next step is how do
you organize a group of people to achieve that social outcome how do you design the group if you
can do it by yourself go do it by yourself goddamn it but if you need a group of people with different
skills and so on then design the group that way to achieve to try to achieve your social outcome
next level down well then design the services that group needs in order to work to achieve that
social outcome and then at the bottom of the list is products so maybe you do you need a do need a
cell phone to achieve that social outcome and let me tell you in my physics engineering education
I never thought that way and if you think that way the humanities is not something outside of the
problem it's inside the problem and I think this whole thing of steam steam heat in England humanities
engineering on technology is no heat without steam no steam without I think the problem is we're
thinking in a way the people thought in universities in my case for 200 years now and that we need
to find a different way of articulating the problem so yeah we need a hundred thousand
white mountain colleges but how do you organize that to happen in structures that want test scores
that want deep up mental structures that and that's why I deep inside me and I hope my provost is
not listening I'm not sure that university is the right place because it's organized in a way that's
antagonistic to the very idea that we're talking about yeah I sometimes feel that adults are not
even the right place to start it's all very top down we're designing for our world in inquiring
minds we work in elementary schools offering students the opportunity to participate in the
process to decide how they want their school to be a better place and what's interesting is they
really know each other they know each other's strengths and weaknesses and they also know what
they want for themselves and each other and so one thing that we use a lot are learning walls where
students can address an essential question that's important to the test they have to take some day
but they can use it to practice thinking and practice collaborating and for us it's really
looking at something bigger that sort of their future there we live in a democracy they need to
be prepared to not only recognize their own individual opinion but also to participate in the group
towards group goals and so they'll put up their ideas about the essential questions and then
they'll start making connections so our oh you said if I ask what is my how was my school like a
community you said well our school's like a community because every room is a different
group of people and we're all doing different things but we're all working together and then
somebody else will say well it was in our room we are a community because we come from different
places with different ideas and so they can take an idea that is science related or math related
or humanities related or art related and bring it into that space I think if every child was taught
that way they wouldn't look like us as adults they would look very different and the thing that I
think is most powerful for me in that is my concern is maybe not STEM education per se and I'm a
scientist so again if anybody's listening I do really love science but it's the way it's to
really equal the playing field you can do this in a school with with absolutely no resources
where their greatest resources their students you can do it in a school that has a lot of resources
their greatest resources still their students but we don't teach students that way and so even taking
problem-based education further sometimes we just need to give space for students to have
conversations like we have this opportunity as adults they don't always have that opportunity
as students and so I would again I'm not a fan of STEM or STEAM although I love a good pun and
it you know a joke coming from a scientist is always funny to everyone but I want some sort of
higher level name that's more encompassing that's not you know something below the cloud
yes I feel like this this acronym problem is something I've been thinking about for a while
everyone's been thinking about it for a while maybe by tomorrow we'll have a better idea I mean
it's it's ambitious but it's possible because we're going to be doing another STEAM panel later on
so we can we can see how that evolves but yeah everyone put your thinking caps on about that we
need to figure this out there's a term convergence that I like the academy published a study about
convergence it was really looking at benefits of bringing different scientific disciplines together
but I think you could also apply arts and humanities into it and it ties in with the idea of trans
disciplinarity that we were talking about last night where these different disciplines come together
in a really in-depth way and the focus is on solving some kind of problem so I don't know what you
what you might think of that term
I like that term yeah I heard of a conference title
oh let me just come back to the to the the adults are part of the problem
so you know when I was growing up there was the Montessori school movement there are a number of
these very different models for elementary education and the problem was when you tried to get into
mass education you know then you get into this thing that everybody's taught as an average person
and there's a test score result so I think part of the complexity we have plenty of good examples of
family educational models how do we generalize those in some way so that it's not just the lucky
